Comment: Except you are 100% wrong. A simple exception to this is due process where a person is allowed bail vs not allowed bail. How is due process always the same if one person is allowed bail for some cases but others with the same charge are not allowed bail? It is up to the opinion of the judge to grant or not grant bail. Why is it that the same crime could end with 1 years in jail but other times it is 10 years in jail? There is still a level of opinions in due process and it isn't always exactly the same. It isn't always 1 + 1 = 2.  **EDIT:** Also due process only exist to reduce the chances of a mistake in the outcome of a case. So even if due process is not followed as long as there is no problem with the outcome you can consider it a mistake but you shouldn't let a murder out of jail because they made a mistake in due process. If in on the other hand there was a mistake in due process that could lead to a different outcome in the verdict such as evidence that the murder did not commit the crime then it should go back to a new trial.  That said if you can prove that the woman deported was a legal US citizen and should not have been deported because she was not here illegally then sure pay to bring her back and go through a new trial. The problem is she was here illegally and she got deported so nothing wrong happened in the outcome even if due process was not followed. I am open to listening to your argument on why she was here legally and should not be deported because she had a green card or something else.

Comment: Background screening industry so we deal with law a lot more than you would think. Author: Viper_Scale

Comment: Well I spent 20 year correctly interpreting criminal events. including telling my boss I will not code what you tell me to code because I think it is wrong including 3 weeks of debates only to finally being told I was correct in not coding to remove records based on bad data I was told to do because It would have ended up with murder convictions being removed from the report that should not have been removed.  **DETAILS:** So i was told when I see records that are merged with certain key words I should remove those charges from the reporting because they were merged into another charge. I pushed back because I was like they were charged with speeding, drug charges etc, and if I merged all these records in the primary charge it would remove showing charges of murder, drug possession, etc into a charge of just speeding that would be reported to the client. Now based on the keyword I was told to use for ignoring all other charges I didn't think it was correct. When it was pushed back to our lawyers in charge of what to report they said I was correct and not my manger and others who were in charge od deciding what should be reported. After 3 months of debating with my manager they finally push it to the lawyers of my company who were in charge of deciding what we should report and they said I was correct not my managers etc.  I ultimately probably saved my company millions in what could have ended up with lawsuits suing us for reporting data wrongly.
Author: Viper_Scale
